posts.cooked:
I am trying to write a logger for our robot code this year. To create a csv file i use java.io.File’s createNewFile command (I added the related code at the end). Code builds but when it comes to createNewFile command, it throws the following error :

related code:

Logger.java

How can i solve this permission error?

Ty

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Aren’t slashes this way “/” not this way “\” on roboRIO (Linux)?

At what path are you trying to create the file? It seems like you’re trying to create a file in a place that lvuser (the user that the code runs as) isn’t allowed to write to.

Also, @SLAB-Mr.Thomas raises a good point: path separators are / on Linux. I recommend using the Java File API to build the full path rather than concatenating strings manually; it handles such things automatically in a cross-platform way.

Aside, have you looked at On-Robot Telemetry Recording Into Data Logs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation ? It might solve your use-case, and is tested more than something custom.

link_counts.title: On-Robot Telemetry Recording Into Data Logs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: oh, i forgot to say that my device is windows and yes, in mac & linux it should be “/”

i try to create it at the same place where logger.java placed. When i tried / threw something like there is no such a file or directory message therefore i changed it into \\ and it said permission error (can be considered as improvement **my computer is windows).

It seems using DataLogManager would be unnecessarily make things harder. As far as i know, after each deploy, one should download them and one can’t locate them to specific folder we choose. But if i can’t make my logger work, i can use it.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Carabelli:

one should download them and one can’t locate them to specific folder we choose.

You can specify the location data logs are saved on the robot.  But even with a custom solution you can’t save files directly from the robot program onto your computer—the robot code is running on the RoboRIO and doesn’t have access to your computer’s drives.  So either way you have to either save to removable media like a usb stick or download it from the robot later.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Peter Johnson gave the answer and I’ll put in a plug for DataLogManager and AdvantageScope. DataLogManager isn’t that hard to use. An irritating restriction is the delimiter for arrays and non-Arrays is different. It’s hard to import a mix of array and non-array into Excel that I like to use. AdvantageScope reads the files perfectly and if its graphing functions are good enough, that’s the way to go. It sounds like you might be happiest with writing to the roboRIO U: flash drive and carrying it to your Windows PC. edit: you are right that the disk space on roboRIOs is limited.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

An irritating restriction is the delimiter for arrays and non-Arrays is different. It’s hard to import a mix of array and non-array into Excel that I like to use.

I welcome suggestions.  Note that there’s a Python datalog reader implementation so you can build a custom export to CSV if you want.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

you are right that the disk space on roboRIOs is limited.

It’s better on Rio 2’s of course!

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the information. I took a quick peak and I’ll look at the Python code more closely later - 7 freshmen and a sophomore on the programming team and we play week 1 and week 2.

I’m thinking some sort of schema will be needed to tell any extract program what to do so the columns of the array data space correctly and mesh correctly with columns of non-array data.

How exactly RobotRIO works with the computer? When we upload code, shouldn’t it connect to the computer we use? If that is the case, then what is the reason it doesn’t have access to the computer’s device or can i give the permission to it in some way?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Carabelli:

How exactly RobotRIO works with the computer?

I think you are asking why doesn’t the Java FileWriter on the roboRIO connect to DriverStation PC if the DriverStation PC can upload files to the roboRIO. Is that your question?

There are a variety of methods devised to connect two computers but the Java FileWriter as defined and used by us isn’t one of them. You can use programs such as scp, ssh, their wrappers such as PuTTY, FTP, SFTP and wrappers such as FileZilla. At a lower level you can write your own using UDP, TCP, etc. The upload from the DS to the roboRIO uses one of those methods.

I thought of an example of what you would appreciate as an easy and obvious connection between computers. Your personal computer has a disk drive called “C:”. A school or company remote (file) server has a disk drive that the PC can access using disk drive called “X:”. Alas, I don’t think there is any such scheme for your PC and roboRIO.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
If you really want to log data directly onto files on the desktop computer, you can log data to a file from a NetworkTables client—for example, Shuffleboard has the ability to save data to its own log format, or you can write a custom client to do save NT data to a wpilog file. This approach uses NetworkTables to handle the data transport from the Rio to the desktop.

The biggest downside to logging on the desktop  is that you are consuming network bandwidth when you send data from the Rio to the PC, and that’s limited on the field to 4 Mbps, so that is going to limit the amount and rate of data that you can log versus logging to a file on the Rio (particularly when you are also running other bandwidth hungry things like camera streams).

The RoboRIO is a computer running Linux.  How we upload code is that the RoboRIO runs a ssh server and the development computer runs a ssh client that connects to it and sends the files.  While you could do the work to set up your desktop with a ssh server and have the Rio ssh to it (using sshfs to expose the desktop computer drive as a mounted location that FileWriter can use), it’s going to take a lot of custom setup work, and suffers from the same downside as using NetworkTables (limited network bandwidth).

So it’s not impossible , it’s just impractical compared to other solutions and has a key downside compared to logging on the Rio and downloading the files later.
